image.altText: Rebecca White in a pink suit stands on stage in front of the tally room, clutching notes.

props.synopsis: It is the third election loss for the party under Rebecca White's leadership, who says it is clear the Liberal Party will be asked by the governor to form a government.

title.children: Labor concedes Tasmanian election, leaving Liberals to negotiate with new crossbench

image.altText: A composite image of Jeremy Rockliff and Rebecca White on election night.

props.synopsis: Despite calling an early election to regain majority government, the Tasmanian Liberals have fallen short. But so too has Labor. Here's what will happen next.

title.children: Confused about the Tasmanian election result? You are not alone

image.altText: A man in a suit wearing a blue tie stands at a podium, with four women behind him.

props.synopsis: Political parties that suffer a big drop in their vote and are on track to fall at short of a majority don't often claim victory, but that's exactly what Jeremy Rockliff did, writes Adam Langenberg.

title.children: The 'victory' speech despite no victory and other oddities of Tasmania's election night

image.altText: An old black and white photograph of a woman in a white dress holding a baby.

props.synopsis: In the 1950s, Tasmanians diagnosed with tuberculosis were admitted to a chest hospital, a facility designed to quarantine and treat patients to prevent the spread of the disease sometimes known as the "white plague".

title.children: How the 'white plague' took Kim Napier's grandmother away from her infant child for eight years

image.altText: A building site with no workers in site.

props.synopsis: The construction industry warns the federal government's goal of building 1.2 million new well-located homes in the next five years will begin on the back foot because of a significant worker shortage.

title.children: 90,000 extra construction workers needed for goal of 1.2 million new homes, industry says

image.altText: A slightly smiling middle-aged woman leans against a wooden post, in front of a beach. Dark curly hair, glasses, blue top.

props.synopsis: A growing proportion of older couples in relationships that span over decades are splitting up, with about one in four divorces taking place after the age of 50. But experts warn it could have significant implications for the wider society.

title.children: Leanne separated from her spouse of 20 years when she was 53. She's not alone

image.altText: Marilyn adjusts Audra's wedding veil

props.synopsis: Marilyn Rulyancich's baby was snatched from her during Australia's forced adoption era. But she never gave up hope of seeing her again — and now she's telling her remarkable story of subterfuge, detective work and sheer determination.

title.children: When Audra got married, she had no idea her mother she never met was standing right behind her

image.altText: Carlos Sainz standing on the podium, being sprayed with wine, celebrating his victory.

props.synopsis: Ferrari's Carlos Sainz wins the Australian Grand Prix, after Max Verstappen retired after five laps with his rear brakes catching fire.

title.children: Carlos Sainz leads Ferrari 1-2 in triumphant Australian Grand Prix

image.altText: Composite of Lando Norris, Carlos Sainz, Charles Leclerc

props.synopsis: McLaren disappoints Australian fans in Melbourne, Carlos Sainz improves his resume for future job interviews, while Max Verstappen drove with a "handbrake".

title.children: Five quick hits — Oscar asked to move over for Norris, Carlos improves CV for future jobs, Verstappen drives with a 'handbrake'

image.altText: A pink building.

props.synopsis: India has denied killing Hardeep Singh Nijjar, but an ABC investigation has found evidence government agencies were searching his family home in Punjab in the weeks before his death.

title.children: What happened at this pink building in remote India could hold new clues in a killing that rocked the world

image.altText: The rooftops of houses.

props.synopsis: Prosper Australia says if we were smarter about taxing land, we could slash taxes on workers and businesses, writes Gareth Hutchens.

title.children: If we taxed land properly, we'd have billions of extra dollars to fund big tax cuts elsewhere. So why don't we do it?

image.altText: Tim Wilson talks to the media in front of a campaign sign for his challenger Zoe Daniel

props.synopsis: Liberal Party backs former federal MP who lost his seat to a teal independent to fight to win it back.

title.children: Liberal Party chooses Tim Wilson to contest his former Melbourne seat of Goldstein

image.altText: Man pours beer at pub bar

props.synopsis: Cousins Joe Bishop and Luke Symonds were in central-west New South Wales for a construction job when they heard a pub was for sale. Despite no experience pouring beers, running a kitchen or owning a hotel, they decided to make an offer.

title.children: When Neville's pub closed, the town went 'dead'. Then two cousins bought the hotel on a whim

image.altText: Tom Gleeson standing with his arms crossed and a serious look on his face. The Hard Quiz has been added behind his head

props.synopsis: Oh, you're back? Something to prove after last week's effort? Let's see what you've got.

title.children: Don't be shy now, you think you know it all. Prove it. Let's play … HARD!

image.altText: Graphic image with Donald Trump appearing above images of Tim Scott, Kristi Noem and Marjorie Taylor Greene.

props.synopsis: A gun-loving grandma, a former Democrat and a MAGA frontwoman — who will Donald Trump pick from his long shortlist of running mates? And will his pick be based on strategy or aesthetics?

title.children: 'Out of central casting': Could Donald Trump choose this woman as running mate?

image.altText: Bill Shorten standing in front of a NDIS logo

props.synopsis: NDIS participants exploited by unfair price hikes can now report price gouging to a new taskforce.

title.children: Government launches NDIS taskforce to crack down on providers overcharging participants

image.altText: bushfire at night

props.synopsis: Residents in Western Australia's south-west face a second nervous night as an out-of-control bushfire continues to burn. Properties have been impacted by the fire in bushland between Pinjarra and Waroona with crews battling difficult terrain and gusty winds.

title.children: Residents brace for another nervous night as WA bushfire continues to spread

image.altText: A big pack of Eagles and Giants players contest the ball

props.synopsis: West Coast and GWS are set to wrap up round two, with Essendon's Peter Wright set to face the tribunal on Tuesday night for the hit that left Sydney's Harry Cunningham concussed. Follow live.

title.children: Bombers' Wright sent to tribunal for Cunningham hit, Giants take control against Eagles

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: Half-time: GWS leads West Coast by 39 points
Quarter-time: GWS leads West Coast by 19 points
Full-time: Port Adelaide beats Richmond by 20 points

image.altText: A man runs the ball during a rugby league match

props.synopsis: The weight of injuries is starting to tell on the Storm, who are struggling to run down the Knights. Follow live.

title.children: Error-prone and undermanned Storm struggling against gritty Knights

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: FULL-TIME: Newcastle beats Melbourne 14-12 in one of the bleakest games you'll see
HALF-TIME: Knights coasting against sloppy Storm

image.altText: woman in a cream sweater lies on a couch with white headphones on

props.synopsis: Climate activist Greta Thunberg describes herself as having Asperger's while others on the autism spectrum, such as comedian Hannah Gatsby, describe themselves as "autistic". But what's the difference?

title.children: What’s the difference between autism and Asperger’s disorder?

image.altText: People wearing bright coloured clothing stand together at a Nigerian school.

props.synopsis: Authorities say more than 280 students and staff members abducted by gunmen from a school in northern Nigeria have been released unharmed.

title.children: More than 280 children released after being abducted from Nigerian school

image.altText: Julia Baird, who has short brown-blonde hair and is wearing a black wetsuit, looks over the ocean in morning sunlight

props.synopsis: One of the greatest myths is that by just being positive, or cheerful, we can somehow erase our problems.What I'm more interested in is the simpler question of: how do we go on?

title.children: 'Seven times down, eight times up': When life is hard, how do we go on?

image.altText: Large radio telescopes in the outback with a star filled sky.

props.synopsis: Humans have long been fascinated by how aliens could communicate — it's the plot of countless blockbuster science fiction films. Yet there's also a team of experts who are investigating this idea.

title.children: Meet the team preparing for the possibility that intelligent life exists beyond our galaxy

image.altText: A close-up of a teenage boy exhaling vapour from an e-cigarette.

props.synopsis: Queensland Health has issued hundreds of fines in its attempt to rid the state of illegal vapes and tobacco products, as the government calls for even tougher laws.

title.children: Tens of thousands of vapes seized in Queensland

image.altText: Swifts players stand behind a sign that reads 'champions' as streamers fall overhead

props.synopsis: The Swifts have proved consistency matters in a Super Netball off-season littered with movement, as their settled roster rode the home crowd support in Sydney to their first Team Girls Cup title.

title.children: NSW Swifts win first Team Girls Cup title in final against Vixens

image.altText: A woman wearing a hat rests her arm on top of a rusted refrigerator while a small dog waits next to her.

props.synopsis: He didn't know it at the time, but Wes Herring wasn't standing alone on the precipice of breaking point — we explore how he and others are overcoming the mental torments of life on the land.

title.children: How the rigours of rural life are taking a heavy toll in the bush

image.altText: Danielle Woodward wears glasses and a blue jacket and white top.

props.synopsis: ACT Magistrate Court documents reveal Commander Danielle Woodward was stood down from the Australian Federal Police after registering a blood-alcohol reading nearly three times the legal limit in November.

title.children: AFP Commander and Olympian Danielle Woodward charged with drink driving after crashing car into tree

image.altText: A woman with dark brown hair sleeping in a bed, made in white linen, next to a gold alarm clock on a bedside table

props.synopsis: There may be relief on the horizon for insomniacs, as new technology using timed exposure to light based on core body temperature measurements aims to move the body clock in the right direction.

title.children: Why we sometimes wake up just before our alarm

image.altText: A police man standing in high-vis next to a police wagon, parked across a road

props.synopsis: Northern Territory Police took a 32-year-old man, who they believe to be the driver of the vehicle, into custody and seized a Ford Ranger on Sunday afternoon.

title.children: Alleged fatal hit-and-run in Alice Springs being treated as possible death in custody

image.altText: A kid throws his head back in laughter, he is wearing a dark green hoodie with a brown fur trim.

props.synopsis: Laughter is one of the healthiest things a child can do, but it means very different things at different stages of brain development.

title.children: Why do children laugh? It's not always because they're happy

image.altText: A man in a swimsuit and chains stands on the top of a bridge in a 1900s photograph

props.synopsis: Harry Houdini had issued a challenge to every magician, illusionist and escapologist in the world — perform any trick for him three times, he said, and he could tell you how it was done. On what would have been his 150th birthday, here's the trick that stumped him.

title.children: ‘It completely fooled him’: How a 27-year-old portrait artist left Harry Houdini stumped

image.altText: Two ladies wearing feathered and formal attire sit in a dimly lit room.

props.synopsis: For decades, women-only spaces have faced repeated challenges from men who say them missing out amounts to sex discrimination. So in 2024, is there still room for women-only — or men-only, for that matter — spaces?

title.children: No men allowed: The battle over women-only spaces continues

image.altText: A woman in a tiara and blue cape in a carriage

props.synopsis: The palace has a difficult job ahead managing the public's insatiable desire for information, respecting Catherine's treatment and privacy, and calming speculation in the digital age, writes Isabella Higgins.

title.children: Kate has asked for a reprieve. Her request will test the palace, the tabloids and her future subjects
